questions.text: A woman presents with fever with chills and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of lobar pneumonia. She had undergone splenectomy 2 years back. Sputum culture on blood agar shows the following. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of bacterial pneumonia in a splenectomised individual along with the image showing satellitism on blood agar points towards an infection due to Hemophilus influenzae.

Pneumonia can occur as a part of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). This is a fatal post-splenectomy complication occuring due to infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. It can be prevented by vaccinating against these organisms within 2 weeks of undergoing splenectomy. 

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Factor V is required for the growth of H. influenzae.

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar

questions.text: A  patient presented with fever, seizures, and altered sensorium. Gram stain of the CSF is given below. Satellitism was seen on blood agar. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: This is the most serious disease produced by this organism.
The disease is more common in young adults.
The bacilli reach the meninges from the nasopharynx through the bloodstream.
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image showing gram-negative coccobacilli in the CSF are suggestive of hemophilus meningitis caused by H.influenzae. Hemophilus meningitis is more common in children between 3 months and 3 years of age and not common in young adults. 

Other options:

Option A: Meningitis is the most serious disease caused by H. influenzae. The case fatality rate is 90% if untreated.

Option C: H. influenze is transmitted via respiratory droplets. Thus, it is introduced into the nasopharynx of the contacts of an infected individual. It has to enter the bloodstream to reach the meninges.

Option D: Cefotaxime or ceftazidime are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hemophilus meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by non-typable H. influenzae?
questions.solution:
Meningitis is caused by typable H. influenzae.

Non-typable H. influenzae cause:

  • Otitis media
  • Sinusitis
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Exacerbations of COPD. 

H. influenzae is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. Serotype b (Hib) is the most virulent and accounts for most of the invasive infections.

The differences between type b strains and non-typable strains of H. influenzae are given in the table below:

Feature Type B strains Nontypable strains
Capsule Made of Ribosyl-ribitol phosphate Unencapsulated
Pathogenesis Invasive infections due to hematogenous spread Mucosal infections due to contagious spread
Clinical manifestations
  • Meningitis and invasive infections incompletely immunized infants and children
  • Epiglottitis
  • Cellulitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Otitis media in children
  • Exacerbation of COPD, 
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Sinusitis
Vaccine Highly effective conjugate vaccines Not available

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

questions.text: All of the following Hemophilus species require both Factors X and V  except_______.
questions.solution:
Hemophilus parahemolyticus requires only factor V for its growth. It does not require factors X.

Hemophilus species requiring both factors X and V: (Mnemonic to remember: HAI)

  • H. hemolyticus
  • H. aegypticus
  • H. influenzae

Factor V- It refers to the co-enzyme, NAD. It is heat-labile (destroyed at 120°C in a few minutes) and present inside RBC.

Factor X- It refers to Hemin. It is heat stable and is present in the blood.

Species X factor requirement V factor requirement
H. influenzae + +
H. aegypticus + +
H. ducreyi + -
H. parainfluenza − +
H. haemolyticus + +
H. parahaemolyticus − +

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency with acute stridor. The mother gives a history of fever, drooling, and breathing difficulty since that morning. An X-ray of her neck appears as given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and 'thumb sign' on the X-ray are suggestive of acute epiglottitis caused by Hemophilus influenzae.

It is an acute inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing.

The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the Thumb sign.

In some countries, widespread vaccination against Hib has drastically decreased acute epiglottitis cases in children by over 90%. However, the incidence in adults has remained largely unchanged since the Hib vaccine was introduced. Despite vaccination efforts, many pediatric cases of epiglottitis today are still caused by Hib due to either lack of vaccination or vaccine ineffectiveness. In adults and increasingly in children, other bacterial pathogens, particularly group A Streptococcus, have been linked to cases of epiglottitis.

Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone.

questions.text: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive is:
questions.solution:
Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive is most likely Haemophilus influenza.

Haemophilus pneumonia typically occurs in infants and is accompanied by empyema and sometimes meningitis as well. In older children and adults, the picture is of lobar pneumonia. Sputum is collected for the detection and isolation of Hemophilus. As the bacillus is very sensitive to low temperatures, specimens should never be refrigerated before inoculation. H.infiuenzae is a Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporing bacillus, exhibiting considerable pleomorphism. In sputum, it usually occurs as clusters of coccobacillary forms.

The bacillus has fastidious growth requirements. The accessory growth factors, named X and V, present in the blood are essential for growth. Catalase and
oxidase reactions are positive. Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. Biotyping has been done on the basis of indole production.

Cultures may be preserved for about a month on chocolate agar slopes. Chocolate agar is made by heating blood agar to 80-90°C for 15-20 minutes. This causes the release of V factor from within the erythrocytes.

Treatment- Amoxycillin-clavulanate or clarithromycin is more effective in treating respiratory infections by Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a known case of diabetes and chronic bronchitis presents to the OPD with low-grade fever and productive cough for 5 days. Which of the following is not a virulence factor of the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an acute exacerbation of COPD characterized by low-grade fever, increased cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath. The most common cause of these are non-typable H. influenzae which lack a capsule and so capsular antigen cannot be a virulence factor.

All H. influenzae have the following virulence factors:

  • Outer membrane proteins (OMP)
  • Lipooligosaccharide(LOS)
  • Pili

In addition to the above factors, H. influenzae type b also has its capsular polysaccharide as a virulence factor.

The differences between Hib and non-typable strains are given below:

Feature Type b strains Nontypable strains
Capsule Made of Ribosyl-ribitol phosphate Unencapsulated
Pathogenesis Invasive infections due to hematogenous spread Mucosal infections due to contagious spread
Clinical manifestations
  • Meningitis and invasive infections incompletely immunized infants and children
  • Epiglottitis
  • Cellulitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Otitis media in children
  • Exacerbation of COPD, 
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Sinusitis
Vaccine Highly effective conjugate vaccines Not available

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria does not belong to the HACEK group?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli does not belong to the HACEK group.

The acronym HACEK refers to a group of fastidious slow-growing bacteria, normally residing in the mouth. These can sometimes cause severe infections, particularly culture-negative subacute bacterial endocarditis.

The group includes:

  • Haemophilus species (H. parainfluenzae, H. aphrophilus, H. paraphrophilus)
  • Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (previously called as Actinobacillus)
  • Cardiobacterium hominis
  • Eikenella corrodens
  • Kingella kingae

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with painful, bleeding genital ulcers. On examination, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Scraping from the ulcer base was taken and the microscopic appearance of the Gram-stained smear is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows the' school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi. This appearance is seen when the bacilli are arranged in small groups, whorls or in chains. The given case scenario is suggestive of chancroid.

Chancroid is characterized by non-indurated, tender, irregular ulcers that may bleed on touch. The neighbouring lymph nodes are enlarged, painful, and tender. 

Other options:

Option B - Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, characterised by chancre - a single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border, with painless lymphadenopathy. Persistent or multiple chancres may be seen in HIV-infected or other immunodeficient patients.

Options C and D - Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2 and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum, characterised by shallow, painless ulcers that progress to painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid:

A. School of fish appearance
B. Bleeds on touch
C. Painful
D. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Chancroid is a painful genital ulcer caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, which is a gram-negative coccobacillus. Microscopic appearance of H. ducreyi is called the school of fish appearance or railroad appearance. Chancroid ulcers have a soft base that bleeds easily to touch. They also cause painful lymphadenopathy. 

The image below shows the 'school-of-fish' appearance characteristic of H. ducreyi.

Note: Groove sign is a characteristic sign seen in lymphogranuloma venereum. It refers to the depression created by the inguinal ligament as it passes between the groups of inflamed inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi does not cause urethritis. It causes chancroid (soft chancre), which presents as a genital ulcer.

Urethritis is classified into two types:

  • Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea.
  • Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with conjunctivitis, fever, and hemorrhagic skin lesions. There's a history of travel to Brazil. Which of the following etiological agents would you suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Brazilian purpuric fever (BPF) caused by Haemophilus aegypticus (Koch-Weeks bacillus). 

Recent DNA studies have shown that the bacillus is identical to non-capsulated H.influenzae and it is now named H.influenzae biotype aegypticus.

It is worldwide in distribution and causes:

  • A highly contagious form of conjunctivitis ('pink eye') which is especially common in the tropics and subtropics and may lead to epidemics. It responds to local sulphonamide or gentamicin administration.
  • Brazilian purpuric fever characterized by fever, purpura, and conjunctivitis which proceeds to fulminant septicemia in infants and children. It has a high fatality rate.

H. aegypticus is named the Koch-Weeks bacillus after the scientists who discovered it. Robert Koch identified of H. aegypticus by successfully inoculating the isolate in one of his own eyes! It was also independently discovered by another scientist called Weeks.
